thread.section_title: Kevin Sherrington Sports Columns - Sports News for Dallas, Texas
thread.title: The curse of Nolan is over! Rangers could be going deep into October
thread.title_full: Sherrington: The curse of Nolan is over! Rangers could be going deep into October | Dallas Morning News

author: Sherrington
title: The curse of Nolan is over! Rangers could be going deep into October
text:
ARLINGTON -- If you were late to the Rangers' party, which, by the way, puts you in the majority, you're in luck. They've booked next week, too, with an option for a couple more.
Playoff baseball at the Globe.
Who saw this coming?
Not you or me, pal.
When Yu Darvish blew out his elbow in spring training, I told Jeff Banister it meant no more fun columns out of Surprise, which was like telling the pope you gave up church because it was too hard on your knees.
"Wait a minute," Banister said, glaring. "There are a lot of good things to write about."
Prince Fielder was healthy and happy for a change. Mitch Moreland was having a great spring.
Shin-Soo Choo couldn't underperform forever, right?
"Contrary to what might seem likely coming off a 67-win season," I wrote on March 9, "the Rangers have the makings of a pretty good team. Enough to be a wild-card contender and make Banister a candidate for manager of the year in the process."
And then Derek Holland went down, too, and I wrote 'em off.
They were easy to dismiss on any number of occasions this season as they yo-yoed up and down the standings.
Nine-and-a-half games out on May 3.
One-and-a-half out on June 13.
Nine out on July 20.
Frankly, following the Rangers was enough to give you vertigo. Not long into the ride, you came to the conclusion the thrill of the climb wasn't worth the despair of the dives. Better to simply assume it wouldn't work out, just like last year. Easier to say it wasn't the 2,281 days the Rangers spent on the disabled list last season that sunk them, it was the Curse of Nolan, the Curse of Daniels, the curse of 40-something years wandering around baseball's wilderness, and this year was just more of the same.
Meanwhile, Banister ran his first major league club with the head of a geek and heart of a high school football coach. The man has an aphorism for every occasion. Also pragmatic enough to get Fielder and Adrian Beltre to buy in and let them do most of the heavy lifting in the clubhouse.
Banister couldn't sit back and wait on his veterans, as was Ron Washington's habit. Washington could afford to wait because of the depth from lead-off through seven. Banister's not afraid to run against the grain, either. His left-leaning lineup couldn't hit lefties. So he handed Mike Napoli an outfielder's glove and stuck him out in left field.
Probably should have given him a helmet, too, but let's not nitpick. Not only did Napoli survive the experiment, the Rangers' record against southpaws improved dramatically.
Of course, he had Napoli as an unlikely option because Jon Daniels picked him up from Boston for $1.5 million on Aug. 7. The Rangers were 51/2 games out at the time. Acquiring Napoli was a nice, low-cost move, roughly on par with most of the moves he's made this year.
Daniels got Arte Moreno to pick up the tab on Josh Hamilton. Bobby Wilson was a waiver claim, Drew Stubbs a free agent.
All have made a direct impact on getting the Rangers where they now find themselves. Wilson and Chris Gimenez held the catching position together while Robinson Chirinos and Carlos Corporan were out.
Just this week, both Stubbs and Hamilton made game-saving catches to put the Rangers in position to clinch.
Get this: Choo made a spectacular catch Friday on a slicing liner off Mike Trout's bat. The same Choo who, on July 11, played a ball into a triple in right field, leading me to write that he "consistently wears the expression of a man trying to remember where he left his car keys."
Reeking of self-doubt, king of the check swing, Choo was hitting .224 at the time.
And after counseling from his wife at the All-Star break? His .457 OBP ever since is far and away the best in the league.
Daniels also proved pretty adept in big-ticket deals, too. In the Cole Hamels trade, he got Jake Diekman. Combined with Sam Dyson, who cost him Tomas Telis, Daniels acquired three pivotal pitchers to both strengthen and lengthen the rotation and repair the back end of the bullpen.
Since those deadline deals, the Rangers have gone from a lousy bullpen to a championship-caliber one.
You simply couldn't have seen this coming last spring. Especially if you were me sitting across a desk from Daniels in Surprise, telling him he had to deal for Hamels, and getting a reaction that said, "Yeah, right."
That's a pretty good poker face Daniels has. Pretty good team he's built, as well. They could be going places after all. Like deep into October.
RANGERS RETURN TO THE POSTSEASON
The Rangers are back in the postseason as the AL West Champs.
The Texas Rangers will play the No. 2 seed -- the Toronto Blue Jays Â -- in the playoffs.
